<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 384, 316]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 870, 637]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 665, 212, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 730, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 91, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
Ellie is investigating the heights of two types of beech tree, \(A\) and \(B\), in a certain region. She has chosen a random sample of 60 beech trees of type \(A\) in the region, recorded their heights, \(x \text{m}\), and calculated unbiased estimates for the population mean and population variance as \(35.6 \text{m}\) and \(4.95 \text{m}^2\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
Ellie also chooses a random sample of 50 beech trees of type \(B\) in the region and records their heights, \(y \text{m}\). Her results are summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 195, 620, 214]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma y = 1654\qquad \Sigma y^2 = 54 850\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 225, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
Find a \(95\%\) confidence interval for the difference between the population mean heights of type \(A\) and type \(B\) beech trees in the region. [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 920, 120]]<|/det|> A school with a large number of students is updating its logo. Each student has designed a new logo and two teachers have each awarded a mark out of 50 for each logo. The marks awarded to a random sample of 12 students are shown in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 883, 211]]<|/det|>
StudentABCDEFGHIJKL
Teacher 1363840362234454448352830
Teacher 2384232413241425036444241
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 222, 764, 243]]<|/det|> One of the students claims that Teacher 2 is awarding higher marks than Teacher 1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 255, 144, 273]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 255, 920, 290]]<|/det|> Carry out a Wilcoxon matched-pairs signed-rank test, at the \(5\%\) significance level, to test whether the data supports the claim. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 272, 920, 290]]<|/det|> [7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 920, 135]]<|/det|> A statistician believes that the number of telephone calls received by an advice centre in a 10-minute interval can be modelled by the Poisson distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(1.9)\). The number of calls received in a randomly chosen 10-minute interval was recorded on each of 100 days. The results are summarised in the table, together with some of the expected frequencies corresponding to the distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(1.9)\). <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 149, 883, 273]]<|/det|>
Number of calls0123456 or more
Observed frequency101835211141
Expected frequency14.95728.41826.9971.322
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 285, 143, 304]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 285, 311, 304]]<|/det|> Complete the table. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 285, 920, 304]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 564, 144, 583]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 564, 920, 599]]<|/det|> Carry out a goodness of fit test, at the \(10\%\) significance level, to determine whether the statistician's belief is reasonable. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 580, 920, 599]]<|/det|> [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 724, 91]]<|/det|>
The continuous random variable \(X\) has probability density function f given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 100, 640, 165]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \begin{cases} k x^{3} & 0\leqslant x< 1,\\ k(5 - x) & 1\leqslant x\leqslant 5,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{cases}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 172, 288, 191]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 203, 146, 222]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 202, 328, 222]]<|/det|>
Sketch the graph of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 204, 918, 222]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 574, 146, 593]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 574, 298, 593]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = \frac{4}{33}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 574, 918, 593]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 519, 88]]<|/det|>
Find the cumulative distribution function of \(X.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 185, 465]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 448, 376, 465]]<|/det|>
Find the median value of \(X.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 448, 920, 465]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 426, 141, 445]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 426, 475, 445]]<|/det|>
Use your answer to part (b) to find E(Z).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 427, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 94, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 69, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
Ansal is investigating the wingspans of Monarch butterflies in two different regions, \(X\) and \(Y.\) He takes a random sample of 8 Monarch butterflies from region \(X\) and records their wingspans, \(x \text{cm.}\) His results are as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 131, 737, 152]]<|/det|>
\[8.2\qquad 7.0\qquad 7.3\qquad 8.8\qquad 7.8\qquad 8.5\qquad 9.2\qquad 7.4\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
Ansal also takes a random sample of 9 Monarch butterflies from region \(Y\) and records their wingspans, \(y \text{cm.}\) His results are summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 209, 621, 229]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma y = 71.10\qquad \Sigma y^2 = 567.13\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 240, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
Ansal suspects that the mean wingspan of Monarch butterflies from region \(X\) is greater than the mean wingspan of Monarch butterflies from region \(Y.\) It is known that the wingspans of Monarch butterflies in regions \(X\) and \(Y\) are normally distributed with equal population variances.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 792, 322]]<|/det|>
Test, at the \(10\%\) significance level, whether Ansal's suspicion is supported by the data.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 304, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
